Sounds relatively generic so far - girls battling to fulfill their wish -  however the show throws so many darker twists into the story (I won't expand on this point, as I think spoilers would ruin the experience of this show) which surprised and intrigued me.

I enjoyed the way the show handled the reactions of the girls to their new situation, it wasn't shoved under unnecessary fanservice or comedy which made it hit home a lot harder, and it made me feel a lot more for the characters.


Art - 8/10.

The art of this show is well-executed. I enjoyed the different battle environments, and the general setting of the anime added a certain something to the atmosphere and later even added to the story. The backgrounds were always nice to look at, too. Character design was decent - nothing hugely original and intuitive here, but one plus is that each character actually looks like a different person - none of them looked like a carbon copy of another with a different style or colour of hair stuck on top. I also enjoyed the fact that each character wasn't defined by the colour of their hair - they all had relatively neutral hair colours, so you weren't left thinking of them as "the one with the pink hair" or "the one with the green hair". But I digress. The only small issue I had with the art was the nose, the shadow of the nose seemed to be outlined rather than the actual nose which gave the characters an unusual look.


Sound - 8/10.

One of the first anime I've really 100% been engaged with listening to the sound in. They are engaging and fitting to their scenes, and they really set up a very intense environment when it is needed and a lighter environment when it is needed. The OP is also worth mentioning - killy killy JOKER - it is catchy and I found it intensely addictive. Also great as a standalone track.

The voice acting was good - each girl's emotion was portrayed in a very believable manner, it didn't sound forced, contrived, or flat.


Character - 8/10.

Ru-chan was probably one of the most intriguing characters here, although she has been compared to Madoka (she's not sure of her wish and whether or not she wants to participate as she doesn't really have a strong wish) I thought her development was unique. She struggles internally with feelings of doubt as to whether she wants to battle and take away other girls' dreams, and the thrill of battle, which is portrayed very well in her interactions. Yuzuki is worth a mention here - although incest is a BIG thing in anime (she is infatuated with her twin brother), which may make her seem a little generic, I enjoyed the way she developed, and how strong her wish actually was (which in turn made Ru-chan a little more reluctant to battle, as she could see how fervent her friends' wish was).

What really made the characters, for me at least, was their interactions with each other. Also worth mentioning is their development, which for a 12-episode series, was handled very well.


Enjoyment - 9/10.

I thoroughly enjoyed this series, and hope the second season lives up to the high standards set by Selector Infected WIXOSS. It was an emotional rollercoaster when it hit its stride, and it left you wondering and rooting for the characters.


Overall - 8/10.

Major distinction that must be made for the sake of rational thought:
"WIXOSS is a copy of/very similar to Mahou Shoujo Madoka Magicka." No, it's not. It's like saying Windows is a copy of Macintosh.
Yes, WIXOSS does share have some obvious similarities in plot structure to Madoka, but it's really NOT COMPARABLE. I could go on and on about this, but I'll keep it simple. WIXOSS has a more intricate plot, more characters, more character development, is more relatable, and most importantly, has distinct themes that are human driven (and less plot driven). Madoka has otherworldly creatures driving its plot forward. Despite what initially appears tobe a similar system, WIXOSS contains the conflict of human nature and themes along those lines as well.


Overall: 10

I greatly enjoyed this series, especially because of how well executed it was. The story flows well and the mood is meticulously constructed in every scene. The soundtrack meshes perfectly, and the voice acting is amazing. There are a great variety of interesting characters, and great characterization and growth. By the end, everything appears to be coming together, but they are only beginning to take root; there is significant further development in the sequel.


Plot: 7

The plot isn't terribly original, though there is a surprising amount of foreshadowing and hidden meaning that becomes relevant later.


Art and Animation:

The character designs weren't particularly special, but the landscapes were beautifully drawn; especially the battlegrounds, which were fantastically surreal with vivid movement; as were the battles themselves.


Sound: 10

The soundtrack in WIXOSS is one of the best I've seen (or heard) and really draws you in. The voice acting is impeccable; both perfectly suit the mood, atmosphere, and tension in each scene. OP and ED were nothing special (to me).


Character: 10

The characters types aren't incredibly unique, but they are very well characterized, very human and realistic, and for some, had powerful personalities.


Concerning battles:

I think it's probably pretty obvious, but the fact that "WIXOSS" is a card game doesn't mean it has meaningful rules or strategy (not that something like Yugioh has such either). Battles are about as strategic as any typical anime battle; wild particle effects are flying around, people are getting hurt, and someone's going to gain the upper hand, for one reason or another.


Rant:

People keep putting spoilers in their reviews. "This is how xyz in this anime works, and this is this main character's situation, etc etc." It's not your place to summarize the events of an anime, regardless of (and especially if) how obvious they are and how soon they are introduced; if people wanted this, they'd go read a summary, NOT a review. YOU DON'T NEED TO SAY ANYTHING ABOUT THE EVENTS THAT TRANSPIRE IN AN ANIME TO REVIEW IT. Most of all, most spoilers given tend to be completely irrelevant to their review.

All a review needs is your opinion on the specific criteria you use to judge a show’s worth, and maybe a bit of reasoning or background information.

The Blues Brothers is one of my top two favorite movies. The setup is that these two guys have to raise a lot of money very fast to pay off the church's back taxes and save the orphanage where they grew up.
The only problem is that in real life, churches do not pay taxes, so...the entire plot makes no sense. However, I still love the movie.
Selector Infected Wixoss's plot is about as strong. Unfortunately, it's not an action comedy musical, it's a story-driven show and as such, having a weak story is basically a death sentence for it. I'm not going to spoil it, butthe problem is that they go for too many twists. It's like if you explain to the audience that falling down a bottomless pit will kill you, but then a character falls down one and only gets a scraped elbow. It kind of devalues any danger presented in the show.


Apart from trying to surprise the audience too much and accidentally murdering the story, the series is nicely put together. The first few episodes in particular show off lots of intricately detailed scenery and the characters presented throughout are likable if a little flat. Animation is sporadic with bursts of insanity and then stretches of recaps so I'm undecided on that.


Overall, not the worst show in the world but anyone with the slightest writing experience would immediately reject that story.


Also, if you care, only 2/3 of the title is explained.

A young girl starts to make friends through a magical card game. Sounds like a fun little anime for boys and girls of all ages, right?
Aha. Ahahaha. Selector Infected WIXOSS...this show is something else.
STORY (8/10):
If my above statement didn't make it obvious enough, WIXOSS' plot goes a lot deeper than that. The first few episodes are fluff, purposely misleading fluff about the protagonist making friends and learning about her new card game. This is to lure you into a sense of false security. From there, the show goes kinda batshit - and it's wonderful. 
There is one pretty obvious plot hole that was never explained,though. You'll know it when you see it.


ART (8/10):


The show looks great in 720p, with beautifully-crafted backgrounds and battle scenes. I only wish there were more battle scenes.


SOUND (7/10):


Both the English and the Japanese tracks have above-average voice performances. Jamie Marchi did a great job as the villain(?) Akira in the FUNimation dub. 


Neither the opening or the ending impressed me, though they were catchy. Could take or leave them.


CHARACTER (9/10):


One complaint I read about WIXOSS is that we meet a lot of characters, but don't get much time to explore all of them. I disagree: I feel like WIXOSS did exceptionally well with the amount of characters it had with only twelve episodes. I cared for all three of the Selector girls (the ones we're supposed to be rooting for, anyways) we saw regularly and their ongoing plots, which is more than I can say about a lot of anime.


While some questions were still left open, I have a feeling that's what the second season is for.


ENJOYMENT (8/10):


Wasn't immediately hooked, but was never bored.


OVERALL (8/10):


In conclusion, this series really isn't for everyone. It has a slow pickup before getting to the juicy stuff, and it may simply be too dark for some tastes. However, if you enjoy the occasional dark tale and a slow build only makes you more excited, this is definitely a show for you.


---


CONTENT ADVISORY: Some occasional moderate profanity, fantasy violence, and mature themes. Best for ages 13 and up.

I purposely created an account just to drop a review and rating because I believe this anime is really underrated.
The cover art (and possibly synopsis at a certain site) lead me to believe that this was a shallow anime about card games and cute girl sexual fanservice for males, and therefore I did not even try this anime when it was released until recently when I accidentally bumped into it. 
A definitely must-watch anime if one is into good unique stories and realistic characters! :D
Story 10/10: 
An amazing masterpiece I would say! Events and contents were definitely fresh and unique. Each individual character feels real.WIXOSS is more of a character-driven story but it is also supported by a really intriguing and well-thought-of setting. Having the story driven by characters makes it much more interesting because the characters have choices and their choices affect the story. Not many things are forced upon the characters.


Definitely NOT a copy of Madoka. Anyone saying that clearly does not know what they are talking about. There are similarities but definitely not a copy. The similarities are "What is your wish?" and stuff/wishes not going as predicted upon being selected as a participant in the WIXOSS game. The entire wish system, battle system and the rules are much more complicated compared to Madoka. Whether or not bad or good stuff happens, or whether a wish will or will not be granted and how it is granted, highly depends on certain situation/condition and is it not as straightforward as Madoka. 


What makes this story unique is that not all characters go through the same route and not all the outcomes are the same. There are harder choices to be made and more realistic and gritty events in WIXOSS compared to Madoka. It's not all about characters suffering because of "story". And definitely not just bad things happening just because it is a "dark story". This story touches quite a bit on what it means to be human, learning about one's desire, understanding oneself, humans' interactions and relationships with each other and how each individual character views the world. 


Good things do happen in the anime, which delivers a much more powerful punch when things are somewhere in between and bad...This show is somewhat like roller coaster ride. A much easier explanation would be, WIXOSS's story graph is more chaotic but Madoka's is more linear. 


I'm not saying that Madoka is bad. It is definitely a masterpiece of its own BUT it is not fair to say that this anime, WIXOSS is a copy of Madoka. It's like saying Gundam and Macross are the same because "mecha" or Death Note and Code Geass are the same because "plotting". Just because this anime has "wishes granting disaster" as part of their theme,  and just because all the main cast are females, it does NOT make this a copy of Madoka. FRIENDLY REMINDER, most shounen anime have a mostly/fully male cast, wanting to be strong and mamoru(protect) others, yet we don't see people emphasizing that they are copying each other.


All in all, it was a pretty intriguing, interesting, brain grinding, fun anime to watch. :)

Bonus points for a few touching scenes in this anime <3.


The only thing about the story is that perhaps the storytelling/directing could be improved-upon. It might just be me but with the contents they have in the story, somehow I got a feeling it could be done better. It started of freshly interesting then there was a slight dip in the anime quality around the mid part, but it quickly picked up its pace and soared its way into awesomeness. :D 


Awesomeness aside, some did point out that they can't relate to the characters and I totally agree with it. I do root for the characters, but I can't seem to really get into the character and be enthusiastic about cosplaying them. After giving it some thought, I figured that it might be due to not having enough screen time for characters' monologue or for the character to tell their story from their point of view. The story of the characters are usually are being told by either another character or by the story showing what happens. This part could definitely be refined more.


One annoying thing (thankfully just a bit) about this anime is that it has a bit of suggestive sexual fan service. Suggestive words carefully picked to make it sound as if the characters want to have sex with each other or that they are turned on, random blushing and gasping while what they are actually doing is just the card battle and so on. But as-mentioned, thankfully the total of those scenes for the whole season is probably just around 5-7 minutes. 


Character 9/10

A character driven anime, and it certainly does not disappoint! Good characters means that you could swap the gender of the characters and it would not affect the story, and WIXOSS is one of the very few who managed to pull it off! Hats off to Okada Mari. <3 


Despite not being able to relate on a personal level, I could definitely relate as a human being. I really enjoyed how all the main characters are portrayed like real humans. No/not much stereotyping in this anime which is a huge bonus point. :D  They are not perfect, some are mean, some are selfish but it is portrayed in an understandable manner. 


It's always nice to see characters doubting their flaws and coming to terms and/or understanding their failings whether they decide to fix them or not. But the main point is that the show shows it as a failing and that decisions comes with consequences, may they be good or bad. 


Art 7/10

The design of the characters are kind of plain. Definitely could have put in more effort in the designs, especially for the LRIG/characters in the cards. Environment and effects are standardly nice. Nothing much out of the ordinary.


Music/sound 5/10

I was rather disappointed by the OST for this anime. There is nothing special, and it doesn't stand out. It doesn't even sound particularly nice. The opening was somewhat nice, but the ending was okay. Music and OSTs are very important terms of having people remember the anime. They should have definitely put in more effort in the OSTs.


Would I recommend watching it? 

Yes! :D


Reviewed by: kyu-erien

I cosplay, draw and sing. :D

www.facebook.com/kyuerien

I'll miss the days when I first became an avid anime viewer, that wondrous feeling as I discovered the unique styles of storytelling each series introduced me for the first time. Instead of nitpicking about formula and cliches, the world was my oyster and I had so many kinds of stories to choose from. But the more I watched, the more narrow my area of interest became. When you're exposed to enough shows, you'll eventually find a group of favorites that very effectively catered to your taste and enjoyment, fond anime and movies that you hold very close to your heart. Some people have thegood fortune of not being as picky and simply enjoy good stories, but for me, I've developed a distinct enough taste that good stories aren't always enough - I hold a deep desire to find shows that could entertain me the way my favorite shows once did. Nostalgia would have me watch shows that try to be like my favorite shows, even if they're not necessarily better than my favorite shows. In this case, Selector Infected WIXOSS trying to imitate my all time favorite anime, Madoka Magica.


"Trying" is the definitive word. This anime is a mess.


Story: 5

The story starts out like a magical girl anime. Ordinary high school girl gets special powers, makes new friends with other magical girls, and confronts a bully 'dark magical girl' - just replace the 'magical girl' part with "card game battlers". The series spends its first-half on melodramatic moping about wishes and desires, some of which I could relate to while others just felt heavy-handed and dragged on for too long; the second-half focused on building up a looming dark twist that Madoka fans could see from miles away, and yet that twist was also dragged on, with the writers using the screentime for all its worth to postpone the revelation until the last episode.


And that's the really big problem with the story. I could always feel like the writers were holding back on us, not fully developing the characters or story properly just so they could hold it off till season 2. That's not how you tell a story, nor is it how you hold the audience's attention so that they might even be interested in watching season 2 at all.


In all fairness, there's a decent enough story here about friendship in (card game) competition, and how you should have conviction and sincerity in fulfilling your wishes without resorting to cheap and easy tactics. Much like the classic tales about genies granting you easy fortunes, working hard for them is much more satisfying. This lesson is particularly enforced when Hitoe Uemura, a shy and secluded girl whose wish is to make friends manages to do that on her own anyway in the process of battling with others, all without magic. But neither of these two themes take precedence because the show was too busy focusing on the aforementioned moping (about unfulfilled dreams) and building up the 'mysterious' nature of the card game. "Mysterious" is used loosely, of course.


And seriously, all that 'dark twist' about wishes becoming curses? It's worn out its welcome since Madoka popularized it back in 2011.


Character: 6

For a show about the wishes and friendships of cute anime girls, these characters aren't as terrible as they could have been. The writers put in bare minimum effort at making the characters interesting at all, but they fulfill whatever archetypes the story needed them to. We have your obligatory ditzy but innocent main girl who's selfless and lacks any wishes (Madoka Kaname), a loner outcast with unrequited love (Sayaka Miki), a cold and emotionless veteran jerkass  (Homura Akemi), an outright aggressive and villainous jerkass without subtlety (Kyoko Sakura)... oh wait, I forgot I'm not reviewing Madoka. Or am I? ::)


You know, at some point, I could have related with these girls' woes and troubles. I mean, making friends is hard, and having someone you love not feeling the same is worse (especially if it's your twin brother). But there is a fine line between tragic and just plain sappiness. When your drama is formulaic, predictable, and having nothing new to say about relationships or anything else for that matter, then it becomes a practice in repetitive whining. By episode 9 or 10, I was bored. Run-of-the-mill cliches don't even begin to describe the kind of relationship turnabouts these characters have in the show. You have school bullies, (t)wincest troubles, idol celebrity angst, and let's not forget the oldest motivation in battling shows: a crave for battling others (from Pokemon to Dragon Ball; take your pick). Then again, real life is all about predictable cliches, so maybe 'slice-of-life' writing like this isn't catered towards my taste - but I'm willing to bet my last dollar that it's just bad writing.


Art: 6

Not only are the card battle sequences too short to showcase any cool special effects, the dark and distorted imagery feels like a poor man's version of Madoka's art style. It lacks uniqueness and creativity, being your average CGI-fest found in typical anime productions nowadays. Blend and boring, I wish J.C. Staff would have at least tried to create a more unique style to set the story universe apart from other similar shows, but that's probably asking too much from a show trying to garner profits for the trading card game.


Sound: 5

Forgettable. I don't recall any cool sound effects during the card battles, and the score and soundtrack are made up of generic music. The opening theme and especially the ending theme are the only music remotely worth mentioning, and even they don't stand apart from more emotional anime songs out there. They reflect the show's themes decently, but when the themes were that poorly set up in the first place, that's not saying much.


Enjoyment: 5

In case you couldn't tell, this was quite the chore to watch. It's not the most terrible thing I've seen. I like some of the subversion they try to do with Madoka tropes, like how the foil warned the ditzy main girl about the consequences of becoming a self-sacrificing martyr, or the way these wish-granting cards can't fulfill unrealistic dreams a normal girl couldn't have done herself in real life (again, reinforcing the idea that you should work hard on your dreams without underhanded techniques). That said, it still felt like a waste of time, watching something this unfulfilling (pun intended). Doesn't help that the last episode wrapped up so poorly either, giving me an unsatisfactory ending only to ask me to come back next season.


No thank you.


Overall: 5

Watch Madoka instead. It's got a hauntingly beautiful art style that reflects the tragic tone of the story, characters driven by compelling and larger than life ideals that make them interesting, and last but not least, an amazing and heart-wrenching soundtrack by the legendary Yuki Kajiura. Oh god, that tear-jerking music, so good.


Forget about this show like the way Hitoe got her mind wiped about her relations with the card game. It will only do you a world of good.

I decided to watch this anime after seeing a review that said it was "Magical Girls Meets Yu-Gi-Oh!" They turned out to be absolutely right.
The most important thing I love about this anime is that there are lots of girls involved in the anime's card game WIXOSS. The one gripe I always had about Yu-Gi-Oh! was that there weren't that many girls playing Duel Monsters as skillfully as the main character of that series. To have all the key players in this anime AND the cards they fight with be girls was awesome!
Besides this, I liked the "magical girl  meets  Yu-Gi-Oh!" concept becauseit took two of my favorite anime things and put them together to make a cool  dark magical girl anime with plot twists and animation reminiscent of Madoka Magica.


In fact, the most notable thing in the anime besides the storyline is the animation. The animation is at its best when the characters are in a card battle. Most of the time, it made the battlefield look like a garish version of The Shadow Realm from Yu-Gi-Oh!. It amps up the tension and makes you itching to know who is going to win and what will happen to the loser.


The weakest aspect of the anime is the characters. The "what will happen to the loser?" question and the wishes of each character are the most defining things about each character. Other than these things, each female "Selector" can pretty much by pegged by a "Dere" stereotype. While the wishes and the consequences of losing makes the viewer sympathetic toward certain characters, it doesn't add too much depth to them either.


While there are many loose ends by the end of the anime, I personally excuse them because there is a second season called Selector Spread WIXOSS. 


Overall, I really enjoyed this anime and plan to watch season 2 as soon as possible. Give this a try if you like magical girl stuff or Yu-Gi-Oh!

When I first came to watch this series, at the episode, at the first minute, I already knew it was going to be something amazing.  It didn’t disappoint me in that aspect,  I wouldn’t say it turned out better than what I expected it to be but it did reach the already high quality I requested from it which is already a great accomplishment which is why I consider this anime to be one of the best I watched in 2014 so far, however I cannot hide that there are some minor setbacks that prevents it from getting a higher praise.
Story: 7/10
The storystarts our protagonist Kominato Ruuko, a rather shy high school girl that finds herself chosen as a Selector, a girl that was the ability to get any of her wishes granted if she managed to be successful at playing the popular card game WIXOSS, and meets the mysterious girl imprisoned in one of her cards named Tama. I won’t head into further details to keep this review as spoiler free as possible.  It may sound fairly generic or an average normal story, but it starts with so many dark undertones from the first episode and keeps growing and developing until the show becomes surrounded by darkness and despair.  A positive point in this story is the mystery around the events that occur was very well executed, giving the watcher the feeling that something is going to go wrong at some time in the plot but not knowing what will happen. Other than they did a terrific job at developing the dark undertones and shaping them until the anime because a bona fide dark psychological story. However the show does have two major flaws when it comes to writing, first is the presence of plot holes that grow bigger by each explanation about the “wish granting” part of the show and its mechanisms and the unsatisfying ending that does leave a lot of questions to be asked, while I do know that there is a season 2 planned I am reviewing the first season and merely pointing out what the first season lacks. Other than that, the card game aspect of this show doesn’t even have proper explanation when it comes to rules to the point where I start thinking that whatever you do is allowed there, and again I am aware that the card game is not an end but a mean however I at least want to know what the hell is going on when there is a battle scene.


Characters:  7/10

Character development in this anime is only giving to the characters that need it, which means our main character Ruuko and her friend Yuzuki are the only one whose personality you grasp and who clearly made a noticeable change with the progress of the plot, the others are given proper development progress by degree of importance to the story with the exception being the villains. By the way, the character of Yuzuki is given more spotlight when it comes development than the main character which is by no means bad, it even made me like her more than any other character, but that spotlight did come with huge consequences, the main one being that they just kind of froze her progress as a character by the last episodes of this show. Enough about the protagonists, the villains constitute the setback of the character department. There are three antagonists in this story, the first is Akira which did a great job at being hated then disappeared after being dealt with, then there is Iona, “the great demon lord” of our tale, which appears a lot more evil and creepy than the last villain and finally the main villain that kept a brief appearance in the first season to be more developed in the second season perhaps, this one is related to the “wishing” aspect of this show. The common point, shared by these different persons, is their obvious lack of background or explanation behind their motives.


Animation and sound: 7/10

The art in this anime is above average, the dark tone is well presented by the rather shadowy colors used, the character designs are not exceptional but not really bad either and the animation shines when it is most needed to affect the watcher either by giving an eerie feeling of uneasiness or by accompanying the already painful events happening, the opening and ending are also good as standalone tracks. The soundtracks are taken from different genres and, while not remarkable when heard alone, are well used to fit the happenings and the change of tones during the episode. I can’t say much about the voice acting other than it was believable and unforced.


Enjoyment: 8/10

My enjoyment largely depended on the other elements of the show, the sound and animation did a good job to keep me watching the story, the characters made the time I spent watching this anime worthwhile and lastly, I liked the twist and turns the story took even the ending that was, in my opinion, rushed and not properly set up. Though I was turned off in some moments due the striking resemblance the story has with Madoka Magica, another show I liked a lot.


Overall score:  7/10

To sum it all up, I am positive that this show is by far one of the greatest this year has had so far. I would suggest it to anyone looking for a dark anime or anyone wanting to spend some time watching a good story. If there is an anime that mustn’t be forgotten in the rankings this season, it is this one.

I was totally in love with this after first episode.
Anime is about making wishes come true by ruining someone else's possibility to make their wishes come true in a battle.
First when I started watching this anime I thought that I would love to have that kind of opportunity... but then I watched it further and changed my mind.
This anime is emotional and surprising in many ways. Sometimes it really made me think that could I do same kind of sacrifices just for my wish to come true.
I love the characters even tho some of them really piss me off.. like Akira. AKI-LUCKY!.oh god..
This anime justleft me speechless coz I've been trough really hard times in my life that I still wish I could change. But if I could change something I wouldn't do it coz this anime really made me think about it.\n\n

Wixxos is a mediocre show, really. The premise is dumb, but since some people praised it alot, i thought it may not be that bad. While not awful, i can't say im impressed. I only watched first season, i don't really care about watching more. Characters were blend, especially the main character and her card. 
Story and characters
I said the premise is dumb, but the story isn't really that bad. There is nothing really good about it, but it's not a trainwreck. It's simple enoguh and very much character driven. And this is where this show kinda lost me. All characters are blend and ididn't care about any of them. In Madoka(with which Wixoss is compared) i at leat cared about one character, Sayaka. They have very little personality and character development, i'd say even Madoka and Bokurano have better character than this show. 


Incest


I like how they handeled incest here. Sure, it's not Koi kaze, but did fine. There is no fanservice for perverts, ans they never say incest is a good thing. They don't say it's bad either, but that's fine. Too bad the brother character was just an empty doll...


Deconstruction and a card game


This is a deconstruction of duel shows, like Yu gi oh, and Duel Masters. But i never liked those shows anyway, so i don't really care about that. Just like i did't care about Madoka deconstructing(just to reconstruct the whole thing at the end, pfft) maho shojo genre, because i don't watch magical girl shows anyway.

But i did care about that card game they play. And the one thing that really bugged me is the fact they never explain the rules. Seriously, they never explain any rules of the game, so most of the time they were playing, i was thinking what the hell is going on. Who is winning? How is the main character so good? I don't see it, because i don't get it.


The ending


I'd say it was anti-climactic. It's also left opened for the second season. Since i don't really care about S2, it was just meh.


Story is 5, art is 7, direction/frames is 5, sound is 7, characters 4, my personal enjoyment is 4, i'd say it's overall 5/10. 

Pff

What would happen if you crossed madoka magica with yugioh.
That's exactly what this anime is, it has the same kind of feel as madoka magica, and centers around card games like yugioh (and many others)
The key difference between the card game in this and yugioh, is that Wixoss focuses more on the characters and the plot than the actual card game, so don't expect any of the rules of Wixoss to be spelled out.
Story: 9/10
The story is quite intriguing, it follows a dark plotline with a plot twist or two along the line. Definetly enough to keep you interested and invested. Like i mentioned, itdoesn't focus on the card game that much, but instead focuses on the characters, which in this case just adds to the story.


Art: 8/10

There isn't actually anything phenomenal about the art, but i personally like the art style, and the battle scenes within the card game are well animated, so that's why it's scored this highly.


Sound: 7/10

There are a few nice tracks in the soundtrack, but there's not really that much to drag this point up aside from the fact that it has a pretty nice opening.


Characters: 9/10

The characters themselves aren't the reason i've given it a 9/10. The reason for that is the way the characters change based on the events they go through. This is a psychological show, and Wixoss hits the nail on the head, showing the psychological struggles the main characters go through.


Enjoyment: 9/10

This might also come from the fact that i really like psychological shows and card games, but i enjoyed Wixoss a lot which is why i think it's deserving of such a high score.


Overall 9/10

I wouldn't go out of my way to call it a masterpiece, but it's definetly a great show. If you like psychological shows and plot twists, i highly recommend it!

3/10
Going into this show I was expecting a lot. But it's safe to say my expectations for this series fell flat.
 First of all the animations seem kinda dated and unpolished. For the most part they do their job but they also don't leave a lasting impression, Mediocre overall.
 The sounds aren't that memorable either. Where this anime really falls flat on it's face is the pacing. Right off the bat we are thrown into a world dominated by card games without much context. As the story develops all of the characters get introduced seemingly out of nowhere at the most convenient of times. Somecharacters even get abandoned without much explanation and more often than not things are resolved off screen. The characters themselves feel one dimensional and not really fleshed out. Oh and the most vexing part of it all is the whole card games as a plot device. It's supposed to be this mystical popular game that everyone plays but the rules are all over the place. Not once is there even a remote explanation of how the card games work. Then throw in the supernatural elements and the game becomes even more confusing. It's hard to get invested in something when you don't really understand what's going on. The games are there for little more than an excuse to induce psychological trauma. While that in and itself isn't necessarily bad if done right, we should at least get some explanation of the rules to understand when things get tense. The whole series tends to run on drama alone and for a series supposedly focused on card games it gets hurt as a result. Also it does tend to get full of itself with how it goes on and on about fulfilling dreams and whatnot but being at the same time ambiguous as to what the exact conditions are for it to occur.\n\n
 Overall this is not a good series. It tries to do too much and gives very little context. I was debating whether to give this series a 3 or a 4 but after viewing it and finishing it, it definitely deserves a 3. It's not the worst series out there but it definitely is way below average. Do not recommend, unless you really want to see for yourself.

Selector Infected WIXOSS [Review]
This is my first review, let me know if it's any good or if you found it helpful.
Spoilers obviously!
Story [4/10]
The story follows girls who are known as 'Selectors' and they have special 'LRIG' cards which are basically alive but can only be heard by Selectors and so the Selectors battle and when they win enough then there wish is granted and they become an eternal girl, this properly feels very Madoka Magika like and that's because it is very similar. It's if Madoka Magika was a card game basically, the story doesn't follow anyone really well, episodes can focus on different charactersbut overall it moves at a snail's pace and nothing ever happens because although the show tricks you into thinking a development has happened in reality everyone is in the same position they were in before and not much has changed. If I was to sum up the story in one word it would be 'inconsistent' which is a massive problem I have with the show. When Hitoe loses her third battle her wish is reversed and she loses her memory about being a selector, however when Akira loses her third battle her wish is reversed but she still has her memory, why? Well the show later claims that Hitoe only forgot because those memories were related to her wish being reversed, which is fine if it weren't for the fact that the wish being reversed and memory loss were stated as being two different things, so the main problem is inconsistency in the story telling and outside of that it's not too interesting either.


Presentation (Art, Music, Etc.) [5/10]

The art is as you would expect, there is nothing special about it. There are no beautifully amazing pieces that make me take screenshots and use them as my IPads wallpaper. There is nothing special about the designs, it's not bad but nothing special either, just as you would expect from anime. The music is bland and reparative at best, rarely making me feel involved and it never captures the atmosphere at all, the OP is generic the ED is forgettable I can at least remember the OP. The show goes for show rather than tell which is fine if it weren't for the fact that it didn't have anything special to show.


characters [2/10]

The characters are extremely one dimensional, the show is even more like Madoka Magika in the way it tries to fake being deep and meaningful when it's really just generic and pathetic to watch, I cringed multiple times when the show tried to be symbolical or deep or have the characters go through fake developement. Hitoe goes through the most developement and she was my favourite character at first but then they hit the reset button on her and once she re-enters the plot she is extremely bland and void of emotion. Ruuko is boring, she just complains about pointless things. When shinji complains in evangelism its for development and giving us a look into this mental state, while Ruuko is just sad because her friend left her and she will repeat the same thing over and over again, it's always the same she never offers anything new whenever she has a sad moment. Yuzuki is hot headed and in love with her brother, wow I haven't seen that before! *cough 'except everywhere' cough* despite that she is my favourite from the show, that doesn't make her any good but she is better than the others. At the start she's about the same as Ruuko, getting sad and saying the same things over and over but eventually she becomes happy and it's so much better and then she turns into an LRIG and she's still got more emotion than everyone else. Plus 80% of the side characters with very few lines have more emotion and feeling then some of the main people and that's not good. All the other LRIGs are even more one dimensional so you're dreaming if you think if going to bother mentioning them. An easy trap a casual view might fall into is that the show is looking at the character's mental state and that this is a physiological show but it not really, the show tries to do this but if you actually stop and think "what did it tell me, what were they thinking, what was the point" the answer is nothing. There are a few more main-ish characters like Akira and Iona but there also pretty bland. Again this is all my personal opinion so you might get more out of it then me but at the same time you might hate them even more as well.


Final Episode [6/10]

Shows live and die by the final episode, it's meant to be a great climax and cinematic piece to finish off the show and leave people feeling like it was great since they're all hyped up over the ending and go into a review with positive vibes. Despite my obvious disliking of the show I was expecting the ending to at least be good and have a redeeming quality. Well the last episode is the better part of the show mainly because I'm bringing it down to one episode, if I singled out the first half that would also have a rather high score. The last episode somewhat finishes it off nicely, we see some REAL development for Tama and Iona gets a bit more interesting while at first she seemed super bland and generic this makes her seem much more real since she actually does have a wish. However the show ends on a cliffhanger and I'm going to be upset about that, not so much because I care but more so because even if there is going to be another season the final episode is meant to tie things off and set up the next season without being a cliffhanger, I feel like the show tries to tie things off and have set up but it's more of a cliffhanger and that's a problem.


Extras [1/10]

There is a 3 episode special out titled 'Selector Infected WIXOSS: Midoriko-san to Piruruku-tan' Specials don't usually get reviews so i'm gonna make this real simple, it's sucks. It has very weak attempts at humour which made me wanna slam my head into my IPad, but I didn't since its new. The only reason I bothered finishing is because it was so short I just decided I might as well, the jokes are weak, the animation is lazy and nothing works well at all the whole thing's a waste of time. It's nice when companies do something for people who bought the DVD but in this case they shouldn't of bothered.


Conclusion

It's so hard to enjoy a show that's bland and boring but it's ever harder to enjoy a show that is trying to be something bigger and failing, even if a show is bad but does everything that it sets out to do then it's okay because it didn't really do anything wrong it was just bad, this show wants to be more but isn't and while I would be sympathetic I can't be since I sit through it all. The final episode was at least done right so the score gets a bit of a boost from that but personally I don't see we're all the praise comes from. I've been really negative this review but it's not all bad, the first half is pretty decent, once Hitoe loses her memory the show starts to go down and it has its moment even a few individual episodes I would give a high rating if I were to review each episode by itself, but the negatives greatly outweigh the positives and you have to keep that in mind if you're going to take the plunge. Once again this is all my personal view if your view is different don't hate me for it, it's just how I feel, maybe the show wasn't doing what I said it was but it gives off that impression which lowers my enjoyment of the show so I'm mentioning it so that you can get an idea for what the show was like for me. Don't get mad if you liked it because I'm not going to argue with someone about this, this is my opinion it's final and it doesn't affect you if you don't let it, however if you agree or don't watch the show because of me then let me know.


Final Score 4/10

Madoka: The Gathering
If there's one thing to be said about selector, it's that you can pretty much rip-off anything - and still get away with it.  Selector Infected WIXOSS manages to do this to not one, but two popular (albeit completely different) brands to come up with its own story to tell.
First, there's the Madoka Magica comparisons.  Anybody can play the WIXOSS card game, but only girls (called Selectors) are allowed to partake in battles to have their wishes fulfilled during the supernatural battles.  Accompanied by another female LRIG inside a card, they can win countless matches and still never know whenit will happen, but if they lose three times, well, that's just one of the dark secrets of this twisted game to determine who can become an Eternal Girl.


So how does a game of WIXOSS work?  That's where the Magic: The Gathering traits come from.  Being a former player myself, the comparisons were far too obvious. The colors each indicate the style of play you use, along with the type of person you are.  WIXOSS is not subtle with this idea, as they literally the use the exact same colors as Magic. White is peace and defense, red is passion and fire, green is the natural world, blue is illusion and trickery, and black is cold, soul-less death.


All this aside, the series takes the opposite route that Madoka Magica does.  Instead of fulfilled wishes, girls are fighting to have their wishes fulfilled. I won't spoil the exact result, but when a Selector loses three times, she encounters the equivalent of despair.


The characters are not the most enjoyable.  They are specifically written to show us what happens when there are a variety of desires to go after.  Innocence, immorality, wickedness, twisted...or in the main character's case - Ruko's - even nothing at all.  In my eyes, she certainly isn't the ideal heroine.  Fighting for nothing but the sake of enjoying the game when you know that beating others results in their despair is a very cruel thing.


All of this aside, I'm pretty generous to a production that makes a creative effort.  I also believe that watching long enough to discover the darkest truth of WIXOSS is worth the ride.  I give it a 7/10 for overall being a generally entertaining series.

Selector Infested WIXOSS is a deconstruction of the card game anime genre. I could make a joke about how casuals would love this because of Madoka Magica and how casual anime watchers love "original anime," but I am not going to. Actually when the anime started, people were saying it wasn't really good because it gave a "Madoka Magica feeling to it." I thought they were idiots because Madoka wasn't the first to deconstruct the magical girl genre and most magical girl anime does have dark materials in them, but enough of me rambling. 
Wixoss deconstructs the the card game anime genre. It doesn't explainhow to play the game and it doesn't use "the power of friendship" to draw the right card or to be able to go through the card battle. Although the second point i mention is a good thing, most people complain about the first  point. The point of a card game anime is to promote the card game by making it seem super awesome and cool. So, how will Wixoss promote the game if it doesn't ever explain how to play the game? I don't see the problem with this. I can explain why I don't mind them explaining the rules of the game from a comment that a anime reviewer on Youtube, ThatAnimeSnob, said. "If they explained the rules it would be like Yu-gi-oh." And no card game anime should be like Yu-gi-oh. They also use the point that you have no idea what happens in the battles. I do agree with that. With no rules explained, you are clueless if you never played the game before, but do you really care. When watching a card game anime, do you really care why things are happening. I mean a card game anime is used to make the game seem cool. The viewer should be concerned about the mechanics of the game, but the over- the-top action that is going on in the card battle.


The main reason why I really liked this anime was because it is interesting(That reason hasn't been beaten to death). Card game anime is usually for children, very happy-go-lucky, and depend on the power of friendship. Wixoss doesn't do this(I mean duh, its a deconstruction.) I mean sure, again quoting from ThatAnimeSnob, "It is a bunch of lolies that have psychological problems playing  a card game" but it handles its psychological maturely. I mean, if this was a generic anime for casuals, Yuzuki would have no problem boning her brother and have "Aki-lucky" have the generic comedy cliche were she changes from happy-go-lucky to crazy bitch instantly in front of everyone, but Wixoss doesn't do that.They make Yuzuki know it is not socially right to want to bone her brother. The dark undertones is very interesting. I also like the anime  because it isn't formulaic. It doesn't go from point A to Point B to Point C and do it over next episode with some twist like other card game anime. 


One complaint I have with the show is its continuity. Not to go into spoilers, there were some parts that didn't make sense. And even though I did say that Wixoss didn't follow card game anime cliches, there was one point where it did use the power of friendship.


Over all Wixoss is a show that you should watch.

This is my first review for any anime. I am not writing this because i loved this anime alot or hated it alot. I am writing this for an entirely different reason.
Straight to the point... is it just me or this anime seems like a copy of / heavily inspired by Mahou Shoujo Madoka★Magica?
Ofcourse many will not agree with me and point out tons of differences but if you have seen madoka magica like I have and really love it, you can't help but remember it while watching this anime. (Pink earrings really?)
Other than that I liked wixoss concept. Art and sound are the bestthing of this anime. Unfortunately story couldn't do justice to the other things. It feels hollow and even forced sometimes.\n\n
I really tried to love this anime more but i couldn't.

The deconstruction is one of my favorite genres beacause thanks to it a genre that looks stuck can move and create the opportunity to biggest series. Madoka Magica opens the gates for Gakkougurashi attends with a creative way the moe, and Kill la kill the magic girl. Also a deconstruction work may be one great series by itself like Neon Genesis Evangelion. This sadly doesn't happen with Selector Infected WIXOSS.
Selector infected pretends to deconstuct series like Yu-gi-oh, Bakugan or Idon't know, No game no life but it stays in the half of it. It doesn't shake the bases so much, it's dark of course butthat's not enough. A deconstruction ponders on what and why we create but it's not like that in Selector.


In selector there is a cards game but among the players there shall be some girls that are chosen to be Selectors, players with the opportunity to make truth any wish they have if they get an undefined number of wins but if they lose three games the wish turns against them. My questions are: why must to be only girls? And why their motivation should be a wish? This two things look like the series copy from Madoka Magica when it's supposed must be elements that takes from the series it supposes to deconstruct. 


Yu-gi-oh, Bakugan, Bayblade and all that kind of series involve boys and girls some even adults and their motivation used to be the fight versus evil forces. Selector infected should attend these tropes but the series disregardes them or at least in the major part of it.


Results that every Selector has a card that is alive and comes from another world that hides dark secrets, that actually is a really good point for the series but doesn't talk about this untill the last third, there are a second season where I wanna believe they talk more about this but I haven't seen it yet so I hold where I'm not speculating.


Also the series that Selector deconstruts are just and excuse to sell toys and when I investigate I found that the game in the series actually exists that says a lot about Selector.


 At the end of the day Selector is not a bad anime, I actually like it but it's a bad deconstruction because it's conformist and that's supposed aganist the deconstruction fights to. I don't recommend the series so much but if you like interest and dark stories this a good option for you.

I was looking for something after I had finished the "A Certain" Franchise (Magical Index & Railgun), and lol, behold I found WIXOSS. I can't exactly say what drew me to watch the series, but I found something unique. First of all, I think this is the first show to ever the flunk the Bechedel test in reverse. So that ought to give you some ideas about the cast.
However, part of the reason I continued with the series was that, from what I can tell, it's an entire original story. There's no source manga or light novel that the anime has to properly pace orjuggle to its detriment. (Looking at you SAO.) It was a strength of Code Geass R1 and it's a strength here. There needs to be more anime based off original stories. 


However, the main problem I had with this story is that it's game is about as coherent as the card game back in Duelist Kingdom Yu-Gi-Oh, sure there's' some internal logic, but the vast majority of the game is left unexplained, besides some vague 'leveling' up and attacking.


The tone of the story is a lot darker than one would expect. Bunch of girls get into card game, some whom are good enough get their wishes granted? But lose three times and their wishes become null and void? Sounds straightforward? But there are darker consequences to every decision and the result of every battle can carry massive consequences.

Spoiler-free
Described as Yu-Gi-Oh meets Madoka this doesn't miss its mark. While having the prospect of getting your wish granted for playing cards, anyone would think this as an attractive deal, but naturally it got a catch.
The story is very well executed. You got a good amount of foreshadowing, which can help you guess the key points when you are familiar with these kinds of stories, still I would say that the end is surprising.
While the focus is on the main story, you still have your subplots which get enough attention that you care for the story, as well as the characters and you feel satisfiedin the end. Most of the subplots get nicely wrapped up, before the finale, others I guess will bleed into the second season.\n
The stories are neatly told, but you won't get a lot of the rules for the WIXOSS Card Game, which is okay, because it isn't vital to the story. You get how the duels work and later on how the wish-system works, which is enough to get the story told.\n
The plottwists are really well established, so that you don't feel cheated when you get the resolution for certain storylines. Overall there is a lot of suspense, which is quite nicely handled and lets you fly through the episodes.\n
At the end you get some more question to take with you into the second season, also a lot of feelings and suspicions. While most of the subplots are wrapped up, it seems the main story is just gaining speed.\n\n
For our main character we have quite a blank slate in the beginning, which is perfectly okay in this case, because it kinda ties into the story and what is happening with her. Still Ru-chan is really likeable. In general you have a lot of trope-characters, which isn't as bad as is sounds. While meeting the other Selectors, especially Yuzuki and Hitoe, Ru-chan gets a lot of character-development, which still is kinda slow, but not a problem.\n
Also the LRIG characters are really well developed. Hanayo, Midoriko and Tama make a great addition to the main cast. Throughout the story and their dialogues you get a lot of hints, but if you're not familiar with these kinds of storylines, you won't be able to put them together quite that fast.\n
Another thing I really liked were the dynamics between the name-characters (all the nameless ones seemed to be kinda bad and ill-mannered). You get a lot of friendship, but some are also enemies. While there are emotions in the mix, I never felt forced to feel something for the characters or the storylines, it felt really natural.\n
There where some minor setbacks for characters introduced but then vanishing, but I'm hoping, we will see them again in the second season.\n\n
I also really liked the music, especially the opening and ending met my taste, but also the music within the episodes was good and well placed. It never felt too much or too over the top. The mix between intense and calming tunes is well rounded.\n\n
Overall I enjoyed this series a lot and am looking forward starting the next season. I got a lot of questions I want to have answered!\n
I would recommend it to people who are into magical girl animes, with dark themes and can take a bit of heartache thrown at them. It looks like cute girls playing cards, but it is so much more!

When I first looked at Selector Infected Wixoss, I didn't have high expectations. The expectations I had were COMPLETELY blown out of the water by this series, that I can tell you.
Story: 9/10. 
The story is very good. Going into depth about the story is pretty spoiler-ific, but I'll try to explain what I can without ruining anything.
Basically it's about a group of girls, Selectors, who have living cards that can grant their any wish if they win enough battles. However, if they lose three games, something bad comes their way. The series is heavy on emotion and the consequences of a card game, whichquickly turns out to be more dark and horrific than the girls could have ever imagined. The story itself was well made, and the sequence of events was also well made. Again, It's hard to explain the series of events because it quickly would become spoiler-ific. I can say that I was NOT expected that ending, and I can't wait for the dubbed version of the second season to come out. 


They didn't go into depth about how the card game worked during battle, but I didn't really mind that. I caught on that you have to "grow" your LRIG, and that there are cards on different levels, but you never really are told how the battling rules go besides a few superficial points. To me it didn't matter, but it might bother some people that they skipped over that. I felt that the anime focused more about the effects of the card game and the lives and emotions of the characters, not the battle strategies. 


I thought that the way the writers handled the despair, heartache, and very dramatic consequences of the card game was well done. 


Art: 10/10.


The art was beautiful. Animation was smooth and of high quality, and it certainly looked gorgeous. 


Sound: 10/10.


Where do I even begin with the soundtrack? Let's start with the opening, Killy Killy Joker. I'm a huge Kanon Wakeshima fan as it is, but I have to say that is one of her best songs yet. The lyrics, voice, cello, and the entire feel of the song was brilliant. One of the better opening songs I have seen yet.


Let's move on to the background music. Missing Parts and Profane Wish were AMAZING OSTS. The piano sounded purposefully out of tune, which gave it a strange, melancholic charm that I couldn't get out of my head for days. Even if you have no interest in watching this anime, I highly recommend that anyone who enjoys piano music should listen to Missing Parts and Profane Wish. 


The battle scenes used a lot of dubstep - kind of like Parasyte did - which I didn't mind at all. It pumped me up and gave it a lot of hype.


Also, the dubbing was great in this show. I watched the dub because of Anastasia Munoz, and was not disappointed with a single character's voice actor/actress. All of them fit very well with their character, and they certainly performed very well.



Characters: 10/10.


All the characters were pretty well written. The characters shown in this anime, as they had a lot of personality. Even though some characters were driven a lot by certain stereotypes (like Yuzuki and her wish), they still felt like actual people instead of cliches. 


Ruko:


Probably the least interesting character of them all, but certainly not uninteresting by any means. She finds herself drawn into the card game and becomes quite conflicted at times, pitting her sane realizations against her growing lust for battle. She felt very human.


Her dub actress did well. 


Tama:


One of those cute-sy bloodlust characters, but of the innocent variety. She doesn't really remember anything about her past, or who she is exactly, but she DOES know that she loves battle, and she likes Ruu. 

You do see a bit of character development here. She goes from wanting nothing but battle to not wanting to battle, as she starts realizing that if battling makes Ruu sad, she doesn't want to battle. 

She starts putting her friend above her insane lust for battle. 


Her dub actress did quite well too.


Yuzuki:


Usually I hate these kind of characters. Her wish is to have her twin brother, Kazuki, fall in love with her, as she has loved him since she was little. Mostly every single anime makes incest pretty unappealing, but Wixoss had a way to make it so I didn't want to throw myself out of a fifth story window. 

Instead of being an annoying, whining, "Oniiii-channnn" type girl, she (at least in the dubbed version, as I have no idea what her dialogue is like in the Japanese version) seemed very human. Yuzuki was a normal, fun, kind girl who just happened to have a wish that she believed was extremely wrong, but was something she wants more than anything else. 


I really enjoyed her dub actress. Terrific performance.


Hanayo:


A intelligent, level headed LRIG who belongs to Yuzuki. She was the first person that Yuzuki told her wish to. At a certain point, I really disliked her for spoiler-ific reasons, but then I realized that Hanayo cared about Yuzuki and was simply stuck in really shitty circumstances. 


Another stellar dub actress.


Hitoe:


Hitoe arguably gets the worst of the worst thrown her way into the story. She's kind, shy girl who only wants to have friends, and her wish is ultimately turned against her in the worst of ways. I felt really, really bad for her most of the time, and started feeling extremely sympathetic.


Her dub actress brought out the despair to delicious levels. Well done.


Midoriko:


Hitoe's LRIG.

Pissed me off slightly. I know she was caring towards Hitoe and wanted the best for her, but if she had simply explained everything when she had the chance, she would have EASILY prevented all the suffering that Hitoe went through. But again, like Hanayo, she was thrown into really shitty circumstances, so it is hard to completely blame her.  


Her dub actress did quite well too.


Akira:


Akira is the "rich bitch" who acts really nice on the outside, but is incredibly sadistic and self-centered in truth. She, like Iona, will bulldoze over anyone in her way in order to obtain her goal. 


Her dub actress was amazing. Pulled out the self-centered, sadistic, slightly crazy perfectly from Akira.


Piruluk:


Piruluk is an "emotionless girl" who states everything matter of factly and doesn't seem to ever be under pressure, even when Akira threatens to rip her in half. I'm quite sure that the emotionless girl is a cover, however, because of the smirk she has during that one scene, which is quite chilling. I loved her physical design too.


Great dub actress.


Iona:


Ruthless and cold, rich and powerful, Iona is absolutely brutal. If Akira is the "rich bitch",  Iona is  the "cold queen who plays everyone into her hand."


Iona is the reason I watched the dub instead of the sub. Iona Urazoe's English voice actress was Anastasia Munoz, who I am a big fan of. Of course, fantastic voice actress. 10/10. Would listen to every Iona line back-to-back if someone made a clip of that.


Ulith:


Out-sadists everyone in the series. Loves to taunt and torture anyone that she can. I loved her physical design as well.


Great dub actress too.


Bonus:


 I love the interaction between Iona and Ulith because it becomes pretty apparent that they dislike each other, but they work together extremely well and have no problems doing so, as they know that they can get what they want with the other's help.



Enjoyment: 10/10.


I was absorbed by this anime. Absolutely loved it. 


Overall: 10


They meshed battle, happiness, despair, desperation, high-stakes game, fantastic plot, fantastic music, great voice actors, wonderful art, and everything together into a solid, high quality piece of work. 


Myanimelist has no in-between numbers, so I entered in a 10 overall. But, if you add the story (9), art (10), sound (10), characters (10), enjoyment (10) and divide it by the number of categories, you get an average of 9.8. Really high score. Fantastic job.
